summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan, outlining the government's plan to obtain and review investigative files from the prior Florida investigation into Jeffrey Epstein for potential disclosure in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. It details the sources of files, the legal framework for disclosure obligations, and the steps being taken to review materials from various Florida agencies. This is a government filing from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan, dated October 7, 2020. It outlines the prosecution's planned approach to reviewing materials from prior investigations (specifically the USAO-SDFL's Florida investigation and the USAO-SDGA's involvement in CVRA civil litigation) for potential Giglio and Jencks Act (3500) material relevant to the Ghislaine Maxwell prosecution, while arguing those prior offices are not part of the current prosecution team.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The letter is addressed to her and responds to her prior inquiry about the government's plan to review other investigative files.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the prosecution case that is the subject of this filing. The government mentions gathering information regarding her from the USAO-SDGA's CVRA litigation files.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the prior Florida investigation (2005-2010) for sexual abuse of minors. His case is referenced as the basis for seeking related files for the Maxwell prosecution.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.context: An employee of Jeffrey Epstein who was prosecuted by the FBI Florida Office for obstruction of justice. The Prosecution Team has received some files from that case.

persons.name: Attorney-1
persons.context: An attorney from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida (USAO-SDFL) who was the primary prosecutor on the prior investigation into Epstein. The government plans to search this attorney's preserved emails for material relevant to the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted this filing to the court.

connections.description: Maxwell is charged in a case arising from the investigation into Epstein's activities, indicating an alleged association in criminal conduct.
Rodriguez is identified as an employee of Epstein who was later prosecuted for obstruction of justice related to Epstein's case.
Attorney-1 was the primary line Assistant U.S. Attorney who worked on the federal Florida Investigation into Epstein.
Attorney-1 was the primary prosecutor on the prior Florida investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, which would have involved investigating Maxwell's activities.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is submitting this legal filing to Judge Nathan, outlining the prosecution's disclosure plans.

events.title: Start of Florida Investigation
events.description: The Palm Beach Police Department opened its investigation into Jeffrey Epstein for sexual abuse of minors.

events.title: PBPD refers case to FBI
events.description: The Palm Beach Police Department referred its Epstein investigation to the FBI Florida Office.

events.title: Federal Florida Investigation
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida and the FBI's Palm Beach Resident Agency conducted a federal investigation and prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: SDNY Investigation Opened
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, the FBI New York Office, and the NYPD opened an investigation that led to the charges against Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Initial Conference in Maxwell Case
events.description: The Court asked the Government about its plan to ensure timely review of files from other agencies for potential disclosures.

events.title: PBSA Provides Case File
events.description: The Palm Beach State's Attorney's Office provided its entire case file (4,421 pages, audio/video files) regarding the Florida Investigation to the Prosecution Team.

events.title: USAO-SDFL File Received
events.description: The Prosecution Team received an electronic copy of the entire investigative file from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.

events.title: USAO-SDGA Designated for CVRA Litigation
events.description: Attorneys from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Georgia were designated to represent the United States in civil litigation brought by Epstein victims under the Crime Victims' Rights Act, after the USAO-SDFL was recused.

events.title: Government Filing on Disclosure Obligations
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York files a detailed plan with the court regarding its approach to reviewing materials from prior investigations for potential disclosure in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

locations: Southern District of New York (USAO-SDNY jurisdiction)
keyFacts: The government has produced approximately 328,863 pages of discovery to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense as of October 7, 2020.
The Prosecution Team has obtained the full FBI Florida Office case file from the prior Epstein investigation and is reviewing it for disclosure.
The government is reviewing files from six potential sources related to the Florida investigation: PBPD, PBSA, FBI Florida Office, USAO-SDFL, DOJ OPR emails, and the Alfredo Rodriguez case.
The DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) is conducting an unrelated investigation into the resolution of the prior Florida Investigation and has gathered emails from USAO-SDFL attorneys.

The government states that the Florida Prosecution Team had no involvement in the current Maxwell investigation and thus, under legal precedent, their files are not automatically considered in the government's 'possession' for disclosure obligations.

The government argues that the prior investigating offices (USAO-SDFL and USAO-SDGA) are not part of the current Ghislaine Maxwell prosecution team, as they did not participate in witness interviews, strategy, charging decisions, or the grand jury presentation.

Despite claiming no obligation, the government plans to search the emails of 'Attorney-1', the primary prosecutor from the prior Florida investigation, for terms related to the defendant, victims, and witnesses in the Maxwell case.

The government will contact the USAO-SDGA to ask if they gathered any information about Ghislaine Maxwell or had substantive communications with witnesses during their representation in the CVRA civil litigation.

The document reveals a procedural effort to compartmentalize the current prosecution from prior investigations while undertaking a targeted review of old materials for potential Brady/Giglio/Jencks Act disclosures.
